markdown: HIGHLIGHTS OF 1980-81 PROGRAMS Helping Poverty's Children to See: HKI Nutritional Blindness Prevention Hunger and poverty strike hardest at those who are most vulnerable: innocent children who suffer from malnutrition and disease. Millions of children are the targets of one of the leading causes of blindness, _xerophthalmia_, a serious disease resulting from lack of vitamin A, which destroys the sight of 300,000 children annually. During the past year, HKI has helped initiate measures to save the sight of nearly 16 million children at risk from this destructive disease in developing countries. **Bangladesh**: With a population of 90 million people living in an area the size of Wisconsin, Bangladesh is one of the poorest nations. Malnutrition, disease, and death at an early age are facts of life. Last year, over 30 million high-dose capsules of vitamin A were distributed to 62 percent of the estimated 18 million children whose inadequate diet makes them the most likely victims of nutritional blindness. This HKI-assisted program is reducing — and is aimed, ultimately, to eradicate — the 17,000 cases of nutritional blindness reported every year in Bangladesh. HKI also strengthened this blindness-fighting program in Bangladesh by: * improving early detection and treatment in clinics and pediatric wards; * expanding education programs for mothers to alert them to the importance of healthy diets and the warning signs of nutritional blindness; * helping increase the distribution of vitamin A capsules to reach more children at risk, through house-to-house visits by 12,000 field workers. Blindness is an added problem for those who suffer from malnutrition in Bangladesh. (WHO Photo) Source: https://www.industrydocuments.ucsf.edu/docs/tzgy0228

chunks.markdown: Helping Poverty's Children to See: HKI Nutritional Blindness Prevention

Hunger and poverty strike hardest at those who are most vulnerable: innocent children who suffer from malnutrition and disease. During the past year, HKI has helped initiate measures to save the sight of nearly 16 million children at risk from this destructive disease in developing countries.

**Bangladesh**: With a population of 90 million people living in an area the size of Wisconsin, Bangladesh is one of the poorest nations. Malnutrition, disease, and death at an early age are facts of life.

Last year, over 30 million high-dose capsules of vitamin A were distributed to 62 percent of the estimated 18 million children whose inadequate diet makes them the most likely victims of nutritional blindness. This HKI-assisted program is reducing — and is aimed, ultimately, to eradicate — the 17,000 cases of nutritional blindness reported every year in Bangladesh.

HKI also strengthened this blindness-fighting program in Bangladesh by: * improving early detection and treatment in clinics and pediatric wards; * expanding education programs for mothers to alert them to the importance of healthy diets and the warning signs of nutritional blindness; * helping increase the distribution of vitamin A capsules to reach more children at risk, through house-to-house visits by 12,000 field workers.
Blindness is an added problem for those who suffer from malnutrition in Bangladesh. (WHO Photo)
